source.6bcb271c:
#import library
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib
%pylab inline
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
source.a5cc1b8e: df = pd.read_csv('../input/glassdoor-best-jobs-in-usa-from-20152021/glassdoor best jobs in America over time.csv')
source.f20979b3:
#transform year to datetime
df['year'] = pd.to_datetime(df['year'], format = '%Y')
source.5a2c2997:
#visualize correlation of each variable using pearson correlation
sns.heatmap(df.corr(), annot = True, cmap = 'viridis')
plt.title('Pearson Correlation', fontsize = 15, pad = 12, color = 'b')
plt.show()
source.f9632dd6:
print('Maximum of salary : ', df['salary'].max())
print('Minimum of salary : ', df['salary'].min())
print('Median of salary : ', df['salary'].median())
print('Average of salary : ', df['salary'].mean())
print('Total of salary : ', df['salary'].sum())
source.cd743c88:
print('Maximum of satisfaction : ', df['satisfaction'].max())
print('Minimum of satisfaction : ', df['satisfaction'].min())
print('Median of satisfaction : ', df['satisfaction'].median())
print('Average of satisfaction : ', df['satisfaction'].mean())
print('Total of satisfaction : ', df['satisfaction'].sum())
source.a5992943:
#analyze job salary and job satisfaction based on rank
job_rank = pd.pivot_table(df, index = ['rank', 'job'], values = ['satisfaction', 'salary'],
                         aggfunc = {'satisfaction' : np.mean, 'salary' : np.sum}).sort_values('rank', ascending = True)
job_rank.head(50)
source.cc8184ce:
top_50job = df['job'][:50]

#visualize top 50 of jobs based on total salary
plt.figure(figsize = (13,10))
df.groupby(top_50job)['salary'].sum().sort_values(ascending = True).plot(kind = 'barh', color = 'royalblue')
plt.title('Top 50 of Jobs based on Salary', fontsize = 15, pad = 12, color = 'r')
plt.xlabel('Total Salary', fontsize = 12)
plt.ylabel('Job', fontsize = 12)
plt.show()
source.eb93384f:
#visualize top 50 of jobs based on average satisfaction
plt.figure(figsize = (13,10))
df.groupby(top_50job)['satisfaction'].mean().sort_values(ascending = True).plot(kind = 'barh', color = 'orangered')
plt.title('Top 50 of Jobs based on Satisfaction', fontsize = 15, pad = 12, color = 'b')
plt.xlabel('Satisfaction', fontsize = 12)
plt.ylabel('Job', fontsize = 12)
plt.show()
source.c75b3007:
#distribution of salary
plt.figure(figsize = (8,4))
sns.distplot(df['salary'], color = 'forestgreen')
plt.title('Distribution of Salary', fontsize = 15, pad = 12, color = 'r')
plt.xlabel('Salary', fontsize = 12)
plt.ylabel('Density', fontsize = 12)
plt.show()
source.b08806c1:
#transform distribution to normal distribution
figure(figsize = (8,4))
subplot(1,2,1)
hist(df['salary'] * 1e-6, 20, color = 'r');
xlabel('Salary', fontsize = 12)
subplot(1, 2, 2)
hist(log10(df['salary']), 20);
xlabel('log10(Salary)', fontsize = 12)
plt.show()
source.f51b9868:
#distribution of satisfaction
plt.figure(figsize = (8,4))
sns.distplot(df['satisfaction'], color = 'lightseagreen')
plt.title('Distribution of Satisfaction', fontsize = 15, pad = 12, color = 'r')
plt.xlabel('Satisfaction', fontsize = 12)
plt.ylabel('Density', fontsize = 12)
plt.show()
source.4349a9df: **Conclusion:** The top 3 jobs out of 50 jobs by total of salary are Solutions Architect, Finance Manager and Data Scientist
source.57486752: **Conclusion:** The 3 jobs out of 50 jobs by satisfaction are Data Scientist, Tax Manager and Audit Manager
source.6c8eb60b: **Conclusion:** Salary and satisfaction have negative correlation with value -0.057
source.7d3f78c0: **Conclusion:** Distribution of satisfaction is normal distribution and the highest distribution of satisfaction are between 3.10 until 4.50
source.d0a92311: **Conclusion:** Distribution of salary of jobs is skew distribution and the highest distribution of salary are between 50000 until 150000
source.80f824a0: **Conclusion:** Jobs which have the best rank are Data Scientist, Front-End Engineer, Java Developer, Physician Assistant
